sourcesContent:
import React from "react"; import { Helmet, HelmetProvider } from "react-helmet-async"; import { Container } from "react-bootstrap"; import "../style.css"; import "./project.css"; const YouTubeUsabilityStudy = () => { return ( YouTube Usability Study | Portfolio

IAT432 Project: YouTube Creator Studio Usability Study

This comprehensive study was designed to assess and enhance the usability of YouTube Creator Studio, focusing on challenges such as user interaction, navigation, and cognitive load for both frequent and occasional YouTubers. The project spanned multiple phases, including planning, testing, result analysis, prototyping, and controlled studies, to develop a complete understanding of user needs and improve the platform’s functionality.

Project 1.1 - UI Usability Studies: Planning and Preparing a Test

This phase involved setting up a usability study with clear objectives to evaluate Creator Studio’s interface. The goal was to understand usability issues affecting both dedicated YouTubers and casual users who might use the platform differently. Key challenges targeted included user interaction difficulties, navigation, and poor learnability, with a focus on increasing platform accessibility and user satisfaction.

Participants: The study recruited a diverse group of participants, from frequent YouTubers who upload regularly and analyze content to casual users who upload sporadically. This diversity allowed for a broad examination of usability across different experience levels and content management goals.

Study Goals: The usability evaluation included specific user tasks mirroring real-world YouTube Creator Studio activities, such as video uploading, managing metadata, analyzing channel and video performance, creating playlists, and adding captions. These tasks were designed to reveal the extent to which the interface supported intuitive and efficient content management.

Task Design: Each task reflected an important feature within Creator Studio:

  • Uploading a Video: Users uploaded a test video, applied metadata, set a publication schedule, and managed settings. This measured their comfort with the platform’s video upload workflow and understanding of metadata.
  • Adding Closed Captions: Users added and synced captions, using tools like auto-sync to examine accessibility options. This task focused on the ease of use in adding closed captions.
  • Reviewing Copyright Claims: Participants navigated the copyright claims section to review and resolve any issues, testing their understanding of copyright management tools within Creator Studio.
  • Analyzing Performance Using Analytics: Users accessed analytics to compare view metrics and engagement data, providing insight into how users interpret analytics within Creator Studio.
  • Downloading Analytics Reports: Participants exported analytics data as a CSV file, testing their ability to use data download features.

Pre- and Post-Test Questionnaires: Pre-test surveys assessed users’ familiarity with Creator Studio’s features, while post-test surveys captured feedback on satisfaction, ease of use, and task-specific challenges. This helped identify specific pain points and potential areas for improvement in each feature.

Key Observations and Findings: Early feedback uncovered several usability issues:

  • Cognitive Overload: Many users felt overwhelmed by the extensive data within analytics sections, which affected their ability to focus on specific metrics.
  • Ambiguous Terminology: Terms like "traffic source" and "click-through rate" were unclear, especially to casual users, highlighting the need for simpler language or in-platform explanations.
  • Poor Feature Discoverability: Certain features were buried within layers of the interface, reducing ease of access and discoverability, which impacted user efficiency.

Project 1.2 - Conducting the Test

During the test phase, the team observed participants interacting with Creator Studio, noting user difficulties, points of confusion, and instances where assistance was needed. This stage provided a clearer view of concrete usability issues and opportunities for improvement within the interface.

Participant Profiles: Participants included a mix of experienced YouTubers and casual users, providing a balanced perspective on Creator Studio’s functionality. This variety allowed the team to understand how usability varies depending on user familiarity and purpose.

Test Environment and Conditions: Tests were conducted both in controlled physical settings and virtually through Discord. This setup allowed for consistent data collection across different settings while capturing authentic user interactions.

Data Collection and Observational Techniques: Data collection combined quantitative and qualitative approaches:

  • Quantitative Data: Questionnaires captured ratings on ease of use, task completion, and error frequency, giving a structured view of user performance.
  • Qualitative Observations: Researchers took detailed notes on user actions, including misclicks, hesitation, and requests for help, which revealed specific usability flaws.

Task Completion Results: The test revealed varying levels of success:

  • Basic Tasks: Video uploading and playlist creation generally had high success rates, indicating relative ease of use.
  • Advanced Tasks: Analytics and captioning tasks presented greater challenges, with users requiring guidance or additional support. These tasks highlighted gaps in intuitiveness, especially around engagement metrics and the subtitle editing interface.

Common User Challenges: The study identified three main usability challenges:

  • Complexity in Analytics Navigation: Many users struggled to locate specific metrics and needed help interpreting analytics data.
  • Unclear Interactive Elements: Interactive features were not always evident, leading to missed functionality and frustration, particularly in the captioning task.
  • Frequent Misclicks and Hesitation: Unclear visual affordances led to misclicks and delays in task completion, impacting user satisfaction.

Project 1.3 - Reporting the Results

This phase analyzed the findings from the usability tests, focusing on quantitative data and user feedback to evaluate ease of use, error frequency, and user preferences between the original and redesigned versions.

Quantitative Analysis and Statistical Testing: Statistical comparisons were made to examine error rates, ease-of-use scores, and user preferences. Key insights included:

  • Error Reduction: The prototype (Version B) showed significant improvements in error rates, with participants making fewer mistakes, particularly in advanced tasks.
  • Ease of Use: The redesigned interface received a higher ease-of-use rating, with the original interface scoring an average of 2.85 compared to 1.54 for the prototype.

Detailed Findings: The analysis confirmed that the prototype’s guided workflow helped users complete tasks more easily and with greater accuracy. Visual cues like tooltips and hover states improved the clarity of complex features, particularly in analytics and captioning.

Conclusion and Recommendations: The study validated the effectiveness of structured workflows in enhancing usability, particularly for new or infrequent users. Recommendations included implementing guided workflows and improving feature accessibility to support a smoother user experience.

Project 1.4 - Prototyping Solutions

The prototyping phase focused on developing solutions for the usability issues identified in earlier stages. The team designed enhancements to streamline tasks, particularly in the areas of subtitling and analytics.

Subtitling Task Redesign: The redesigned interface introduced a guided workflow, with clear stages and options for subtitling:

  • Step-by-Step Workflow: Users were guided through each stage, from language selection to editing, with clear instructions at each step to reduce confusion.
  • Card-Based Subtitle Options: Different captioning methods (e.g., auto-sync, manual input) were presented as card options with icons and descriptions, helping users understand each method easily.

Analytics Page Redesign: Key changes were made to simplify the analytics interface and improve navigation:

  • Highlighted Metrics: Essential metrics were prioritized and displayed first, making them easier to locate and reducing cognitive load.
  • Terminology Tooltips: Hoverable tooltips provided definitions for analytics terms, assisting users who were unfamiliar with complex data terminology.

Advanced Analytics Enhancements: Additional features included:

  • Informed Metric Selection with Tooltips: Hoverable tooltips for each metric helped users understand options, making data interpretation easier.
  • Search Functionality: A search bar allowed users to filter metrics by keywords, streamlining navigation and reducing cognitive load.

Testing and Results: Prototype testing showed significant improvements in ease of use, particularly for novice users. The guided structure and helpful tooltips made complex tasks more approachable and reduced error rates.

Project 3 - Controlled Studies

This phase involved a controlled study comparing the original Subtitle Editor with the redesigned prototype. The aim was to assess whether a step-by-step interface could reduce user errors and improve ease of use.

Hypothesis and Study Design: The hypothesis proposed that the prototype would result in fewer errors and smoother task completion. 26 participants were divided into two groups to test the original and redesigned versions, following pre-defined instructions for adding subtitles.

Data Collection: Data collection included pre- and post-test questionnaires, along with observations on interactions like misclicks and hint requests. Both qualitative and quantitative data helped measure usability differences.

Results: Key findings included:

  • Error Reduction: The redesigned version showed a notable reduction in error rates, particularly in tasks requiring guidance, with fewer requests for hints.
  • Ease-of-Use Ratings: The prototype received significantly higher ease-of-use ratings, confirming that a structured task flow enhances navigation.
  • Reduced Confusion: Observations showed fewer instances of confusion with the prototype, attributed to clearer guidance and visual cues.

Conclusion and Recommendations: The study validated the benefit of a guided workflow in improving user experience. Recommendations included implementing guided task flows, enhanced tooltips, and onboarding options to improve usability for users of all experience levels.

 ); }; export default YouTubeUsabilityStudy;
